meanings.definition: To treat with contempt or disdain.
meanings.sent1: She would outscorn anyone who dared to challenge her authority.
meanings.sent2: The bully would often outscorn his classmates to make himself feel superior.
meanings.sent3: The cat seemed to outscorn the new toy, preferring to play with an old sock instead.
meanings.sent4: His outscorn for the rules was evident in his rebellious attitude towards authority.
meanings.sent5: The villain's outscorn for the hero only fueled the rivalry between them.

meanings.definition: To scorn or ridicule someone or something.
meanings.sent1: The mean girl would outscorn anyone who didn't meet her standards of beauty.
meanings.sent2: The comedian would often outscorn politicians in his stand-up routines.
meanings.sent3: The toddler seemed to outscorn the broccoli on his plate, making faces at it.
meanings.sent4: Her outscorn towards the new fashion trend was clear from the eye rolls she gave.
meanings.sent5: The outscorn in his tone made it clear he was not impressed with the proposal.
